section.title: Auxiliary verbs be, have, do
section.sectiontitle: We can use be, do and have as main verbs but we often use them as auxiliary verbs to form tenses, questions, negative forms or on their own.
section.text1a: Stuart does about two hours homework every night.
section.sectiontitle2: We use be (+ verb + -ing) to form the continuous tenses.
section.text3a: He's studying to become a doctor.
section.text4a: I was talking to Charles the other day.

section.title: Auxiliary verbs be, have, do
section.sectiontitle: We use have (+ past participle) to form perfect tenses and have got for possession.
section.text1a: We've been here for three months.
section.sectiontitle2: We use do (+ verb) to form the questions and negatives of simple tenses.

section.title: Auxiliary verbs be, have, do
section.sectiontitle: In questions in continuous and perfect tenses, we invert the subject and the auxiliary verb.
section.text2: You've lived here for ten years.
section.sectiontitle2: In negatives in continuous and perfect tenses, we use auxiliary verb + not. We usually use the short form n't.

section.title: Auxiliary verbs be, have, do
section.sectiontitle: We can use auxiliary verbs on their own in short answers.
section.text2: Do your parents live in Paris?
